items.title: 'We were in real danger': Australian who fled Iran recalls night crackdown arrived
items.description: On a visit to his hometown outside Tehran, this Iranian Australian joined the protests last Thursday night, then the regime's suppression methods turned from tear gas to live fire.

items.title: IMF awaits shareholder backing before aiding Venezuela
items.description:
The International Monetary Fund stands ready to support Venezuela, but must first receive backing from its major shareholders to recognize the country's post-Maduro leadership before any assistance can flow, Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said Thursday.

"If there is an opportunity to support the people of Venezuela, you can be sure the Fund will be there," Georgieva told Reuters during a visit to Ukraine. The remarks came nearly two weeks after U.S. forces removed former President Nicolás Maduro in a January 3 military operation, leaving acting President Delcy Rodríguez to navigate the country's economic turmoil.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Interstellar comet's sunward jets baffle scientists

featured_image.name: Rare interstellar comet 3i/Atlas set to fly past Earth ...

items.description:
The third known interstellar object to visit our solar system continues to puzzle astronomers as it exits toward Jupiter, displaying sunward jets that defy conventional comet physics while yielding no detectable alien signals to radio telescopes scanning for signs of extraterrestrial technology.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, first spotted on July 1, 2025, by the NASA-funded ATLAS survey in Chile, has been the subject of intense scientific scrutiny since its discovery. With the Breakthrough Listen project confirming no technosignatures were detected during five hours of observation using the Green Bank Telescope on December 18, 2025, researchers have largely settled the question of whether this cosmic wanderer might be artificial.[1][2][3]

"We all would have been thrilled to find technosignatures coming from 3I/ATLAS, but they're just not there," Benjamin Jacobson-Bell from the University of California, Berkeley, told Space.com. "Finding no signals was the result we expected, due to the significant evidence for 3I/ATLAS being a comet with only natural features."[4]

items.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro ordered transferred to maximum-security prison
items.description:
Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes ordered the transfer of former President Jair Bolsonaro to the Papuda Penitentiary Complex in Brasilia on Thursday, according to court documents released January 15, 2026. The move represents a stark shift in the conditions under which the 70-year-old far-right politician will serve his 27-year sentence for plotting a coup following his 2022 election defeat.[1][2][3]

Bolsonaro has been detained at the Federal Police Superintendency since his arrest in late November 2025, housed in a 12-square-meter room equipped with a bed, private bathroom, air conditioning, television, and desk. Under the new order, he will be relocated to a building within the Papuda complex, Brazil's largest maximum-security penitentiary facility in the capital.[4][5][6][7]

items.title: Venezuelan opposition leader 'presents' her Nobel Peace Prize to Trump
items.description: Maria Corina Machado says she presented Donald Trump with her Nobel Peace Prize medal during a meeting in Washington earlier today but did not say whether he accepted it.

items.title: Venezuela's acting president proposes oil reforms to lure US investment

featured_image.name: Delcy Rodriguez Addresses The Media Regarding The Release Of Prisoners In Venezuela

items.description:
Acting Venezuelan President Delcy Rodríguez has submitted a proposal to reform her country's hydrocarbon law, seeking to open doors to greater US investment in the oil-rich nation less than two weeks after US special forces captured former President Nicolás Maduro in a surprise military operation.[1][2]

Rodríguez announced on Thursday that she was proposing the reforms to Venezuela's National Assembly, a move that addresses a key demand from major American oil companies who have described the country as "uninvestable" under current regulations. At her first press conference since Maduro's ouster, Rodríguez also declared Venezuela was entering a "new political era" marked by greater tolerance toward political rivals.[3][4][1]

items.title: Global AI spending to surge 44% in 2026, Gartner forecasts

featured_image.name: CEO Jensen Huang Just Delivered Fantastic News for Nvidia Investors | The Motley Fool

items.description: The artificial intelligence industry is on track for a historic year, with global spending projected to surge 44% to $2.53 trillion in 2026 before climbing to $3.33 trillion by 2027, according to new forecasts from Gartner released this week. The boom is simultaneously propelling semiconductor revenues past $1 trillion for the first time in the industry's history.

items.title: Family questions hospital care after woman dies from bloodstream infection
items.description: Struggling to find answers about what happened in the week leading up to her death in hospital, Sue Smith's loved ones say they want hospitals to put more resources into investigating these types of incidents.

items.title: Zaida's son was snatched in the night and she's begging for his release
items.description: Venezuela's new leader says political prisoners are being freed, but hundreds remain jailed, with families clinging to hope that America's intervention and ongoing pressure will eventually secure their loved ones' release

items.title: US and Taiwan reach trade deal cutting tariffs, securing chip investment

featured_image.name: TSMC, the Chip Giant, Is to Spend $100 Billion in U.S. Over the Next ...

items.description:
The United States and Taiwan have reached a trade agreement that will reduce tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 percent to 15 percent and secure hundreds of billions of dollars in semiconductor investment commitments, according to officials familiar with the matter. The deal, which the White House was set to announce Thursday, places Taiwan on equal footing with Japan and South Korea, which secured similar arrangements last year.[1][2]

Under the agreement, Taiwanese semiconductor companies will commit to a $500 billion increase in financing for American operations, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. pledging to build at least five additional fabrication plants in Arizona, effectively doubling its manufacturing presence in the state.[2][3][1]

items.title: Trump advisers warned Iran strike unlikely to topple regime

featured_image.name: Trump would want military action in Iran to be swift and decisive ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump's national security advisers have cautioned him that a substantial military strike against Iran would probably not lead to the collapse of the Islamic Republic's government and could instead trigger a wider regional conflict, according to U.S. officials familiar with the discussions. The assessment came as Trump signaled a potential pause in his escalating threats against Tehran, saying Wednesday he had been informed that killings of protesters had stopped.

The president has communicated to his advisers that he wants any military action to be "swift and decisive" and deliver a "definitive" blow to the regime, according to NBC News. However, officials said his team has been unable to guarantee that outcome, with concerns mounting that the United States may lack sufficient military assets in the region to defend against what is expected to be an aggressive Iranian response.[1][2]

items.title: Deforestation pushing mosquitoes to bite humans more, study finds

featured_image.name: Mosquitoes' thirst for human blood has increased as ...

items.description:
As Brazil's Atlantic Forest shrinks and wildlife vanishes, mosquitoes are increasingly targeting humans for their blood meals, raising fresh concerns about the spread of diseases such as dengue, Zika, and yellow fever, according to a study published this week in Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution.

The research, conducted by scientists at the Oswaldo Cruz Institute and the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, analyzed blood samples from mosquitoes captured in nature reserves within the Atlantic Forest. The results showed a pronounced shift: of the identifiable blood meals, 18 came from humans—far outpacing other sources, which included only six birds, one amphibian, one rodent, and one canid.[1][2][3]

items.title: Future of Bondi terror attack bridge on hold after local opposition
items.description: Waverley Council held an extraordinary meeting last night, but the future of the footbridge used by the Bondi gunmen remains undecided.

items.title: Netanyahu asked Trump to delay Iran strike, officials say

featured_image.name: Netanyahu plans to brief Trump on possible new Iran strikes

items.description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked President Donald Trump on Wednesday to hold off on a military strike against Iran, according to senior U.S. officials, as four Arab nations conducted urgent diplomacy to avert an American attack that they feared could destabilize the region.

The request from Netanyahu came as Trump appeared to pull back from the brink of military action, telling reporters Wednesday that he had been informed by "very, very important sources on the other side" that the killing of protesters in Iran had stopped and planned executions would not take place.[1][2][3]

items.title: Piecing together satellite images shows bushfire crisis unfolding
items.description: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

items.title: Households 'paid to switch off' as extreme weather stalks power grid
items.description: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

items.title: PM gears up for fight with Liberal premiers on gun buybacks
items.description: A split is emerging at a state level over the government's plan to establish a national gun buyback scheme following the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: Beach towns in shock after 'terrifying' historic deluge, flash flooding on Great Ocean Road
items.description: Camping spots near Lorne are surveying the wreckage today after record-breaking rains turned into "terrifying" floodwaters along Victoria's Great Ocean Road, sweeping cars into the ocean and inundating two holiday parks.

items.title: Canada and China sign trade roadmap as Carney makes first Beijing visit in 8 years

featured_image.name: Canadian prime minister visits China after nearly a decade of tense ...

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and China's top officials signaled a major shift in bilateral relations Thursday as the two countries signed an economic and trade cooperation roadmap alongside six initial agreements covering energy, food safety, and other sectors during the first visit to Beijing by a Canadian leader in eight years.

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi characterized Carney's four-day state visit as a "turning point" in ties between the two nations, telling Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Anita Anand that the progress would "open up new prospects for bilateral relations" amid what he described as "unprecedented and complex changes taking place in the world."[1][2][3]

items.title: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows
items.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
